Product placement is critical for retailers. But which SKUs the item sits next to is just as important as where it’s actually placed in your store. 
 
For instance, sales increased in this article directly because of product placement. Specifically, because Costco customers enjoyed digging through multi-product displays to find discounts. It’s a great example of how proximal items can affect the sales of other items. 
 
We see this all the time with the data from FieldStack, but it’s not just discount or clearance items that see a jump in sales. Sometimes, it sort of happens in the reverse. We’ve seen cases where retailers removed the poor-performing items and the items left behind stopped selling as well. And why is that? Well, with certain kinds of goods, the customer wants to see poorer versions nearby to make them feel better about their purchase. 
 
This is why we encourage retailers to look at the whole picture before dropping SKUs. Most retailers are familiar with SKU optimization where you remove items that are underperforming, but this concept is too narrow and doesn’t take into account how certain items perform together. You don’t want to pull items off the shelf just to find that it has a negative impact on your other SKUs.  
 
When you look at section optimization over SKU optimization, you can determine how different SKUs impact each other and which SKUs should be in each section – effectively optimizing your entire store. This is something you can predict and measure with the right analytics. And it’s something that we love to do with FieldStack.

Great to see the important work of Maine Boys to Men covered in the Huffington Post!  In Maine, there’s a great example of what prevention might look like. Maine Boys To Men is a nonprofit aimed at reducing violence against women and girls by focusing on positive expressions of masculinity.

The program targets middle school boys for a good reason, said executive director Matt Theodores.  “By the time boys reach high school, they have become very accepting of traditional masculine stereotypes and are far less open to ideas that challenge those norms,” he said.  Middle-school-aged boys have the maturity and enough life experience to have real discussions about gender-related pressures and the impact this has on them and others.”

More importantly, they’re given the language to talk about a broader view of manhood ― one in which men can be self-aware and socially conscious. They’re reassured that masculinity isn’t inherently bad and that men can forge healthy, authentic relationships, be vulnerable and seek help when they need it.
